UI_visible_response: The zero-COVID policy in China had several significant effects on both the economy and society. Economically, it led to a reduction of around 3.9% in GDP in 2022, as indicated by back-of-the-envelope calculations2. The policy also severely impacted tourism, with foreign tourism almost non-existent and the internal tourism market struggling despite some growth instances1. Additionally, rural villages were isolated from urban markets and tourists, which affected the livelihoods of their inhabitants8. Socially, nearly every city was under various forms of lockdown for three years, with as many as 370 million people isolated in their homes at the policy's peak7. On the other hand, one of the disadvantages of the zero-COVID policy was that the low number of infections resulted in a low level of immunity among the population5.
traffic_visible_response: The zero-COVID policy in China had several significant effects on both the economy and society. Economically, it led to a reduction of around 3.9% in GDP in 2022, as indicated by back-of-the-envelope calculations [[2]]. The policy also severely impacted tourism, with foreign tourism almost non-existent and the internal tourism market struggling despite some growth instances [[1]]. Additionally, rural villages were isolated from urban markets and tourists, which affected the livelihoods of their inhabitants [[8]]. Socially, nearly every city was under various forms of lockdown for three years, with as many as 370 million people isolated in their homes at the policy's peak [[7]]. On the other hand, one of the disadvantages of the zero-COVID policy was that the low number of infections resulted in a low level of immunity among the population [[5]].
